rev.comment: /* Emergency law */ image removed [Copyright violation and irrelevant]
rev.diff:
Line 40: Line 40:
===Emergency law===
===Emergency law===
{{main|Emergency law in Egypt}}
{{main|Emergency law in Egypt}}
â
[[File:Che Toka.jpg|thumb|Muslim Protesters and Military Personnel Pray side by side on Jan 30th, 2011]]
 
An [[Emergency law in Egypt|emergency law]] (Law No. 162 of 1958) was enacted after the 1967 [[Six-Day War]], suspended for 18 months in the early 1980s,<ref name="emerlaw">[http://www.emerglobal.com/lex/law-1958-162 Law 1958/162 (Emergency Law)] {{ar}} at [http://www.emerglobal.com/lex EMERglobal Lex] January 2011, part of the [[Edinburgh Middle East Report]]. Retrieved 2 April 2010.</ref> and continuously in effect since President Sadat's 1981 assassination.<ref name="eohr2008">{{cite web|last=Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights|title=Egypt and The Impact of 27 years of Emergency on Human Rights|url=http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110129202417/http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archivedate=29 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=28 May 2008}}</ref> Under the law, police powers are extended, [[Constitution of Egypt|constitutional rights]] suspended, [[censorship]] is legalized,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://conconflicts.ssrc.org/mideast/shehata/|title=Egypt After 9/11: Perceptions of the United States|date=26 March 2004|accessdate=30 January 2011|last=Shehata|first=Samer|work=Contemporary Conflicts}}</ref> and the government may imprison individuals indefinitely and without reason. The law sharply limits any non-governmental political activity, including [[Demonstration (people)|street demonstrations]], non-approved political organizations, and unregistered financial donations.<ref name="emerlaw" /> The Mubarak government has cited the threat of [[terrorism]] in order to extend the emergency law,<ref name="eohr2008" /> claiming that opposition groups like the [[Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]] could come into power in Egypt if the current government did not forgo [[parliamentary elections]] and suppressed the group through actions allowed under emergency law.<ref name="autogenerated2004">{{Cite book|last= Caraley|first= Demetrios|title= American Hegemony: Preventive War, Iraq, and Imposing Democracy|publisher=[[Academy of Political Science]]|year= 2004|month= April|isbn= 1-8848-5304-8}}</ref> This has led to the imprisonment of activists without trials,<ref name="Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation">{{cite web|author=Choney, Suzanne|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41285248/ns/technology_and_science-tech_and_gadgets/|title=Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[MSNBC]]}}</ref> illegal undocumented hidden detention facilities,<ref name="Mayer">{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/10/30/061030ta_talk_mayer|title=The C.I.A.'s Travel Agent|date= 30 October 2006|accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[The New Yorker]] |author=Mayer, Jane}}</ref><ref name="Kalla fakta">{{cite web|url=http://www.trojkan.se/temp/Reportage/KF_Extraordinary_Rendition/English_version/The%20Broken%20Promise%20-%20%20How%20we%20did%20it.doc|title=Striptease brevpapperl Agent|date= 18 May 2004|accessdate=28 January 2011|publisher=trojkan.se|author=Fakta, Kalla}}</ref> and rejecting university, mosque, and newspaper staff members based on their political inclination.<ref name="independents fight for hearts and minds">{{cite web|author=Shenker, Jack|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/nov/22/egypt-elections-muslim-brotherhood-ndp|title=Egyptian Elections: Independents Fight for Hearts and Minds in 'Fixed Ballot'|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=22 November 2010|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> A [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|parliamentary election]] in December 2010 was preceded by a media crackdown, arrests, candidate bans (particularly of the Muslim Brotherhood), and allegations of fraud involving the near unanimous victory by the ruling party in parliament.<ref name="emerlaw" /> Human rights organizations estimate that in 2010 between 5,000 and 10,000 people were in long-term detention without charge or trial.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Press release]]|publisher=[[Amnesty International]]|title=Egypt: Keep Promise to Free Detainees by End of June: Joint Statement|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/MDE12/027/2010/en|date=29 June 2010|accessdate=4 February 2011|date=29 June 2010}}</ref><ref name="Death Triggers Cairo Protests">{{cite web|author=Holder, R. Clemente|url=http://www.washington-report.org/backissues/0794/9407060.htm|title=Egyptian Lawyer's Death Triggers Cairo Protests|work=[[Washington Report on Middle East Affairs]]|date=July/August 1994|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
An [[Emergency law in Egypt|emergency law]] (Law No. 162 of 1958) was enacted after the 1967 [[Six-Day War]], suspended for 18 months in the early 1980s,<ref name="emerlaw">[http://www.emerglobal.com/lex/law-1958-162 Law 1958/162 (Emergency Law)] {{ar}} at [http://www.emerglobal.com/lex EMERglobal Lex] January 2011, part of the [[Edinburgh Middle East Report]]. Retrieved 2 April 2010.</ref> and continuously in effect since President Sadat's 1981 assassination.<ref name="eohr2008">{{cite web|last=Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights|title=Egypt and The Impact of 27 years of Emergency on Human Rights|url=http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110129202417/http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archivedate=29 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=28 May 2008}}</ref> Under the law, police powers are extended, [[Constitution of Egypt|constitutional rights]] suspended, [[censorship]] is legalized,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://conconflicts.ssrc.org/mideast/shehata/|title=Egypt After 9/11: Perceptions of the United States|date=26 March 2004|accessdate=30 January 2011|last=Shehata|first=Samer|work=Contemporary Conflicts}}</ref> and the government may imprison individuals indefinitely and without reason. The law sharply limits any non-governmental political activity, including [[Demonstration (people)|street demonstrations]], non-approved political organizations, and unregistered financial donations.<ref name="emerlaw" /> The Mubarak government has cited the threat of [[terrorism]] in order to extend the emergency law,<ref name="eohr2008" /> claiming that opposition groups like the [[Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]] could come into power in Egypt if the current government did not forgo [[parliamentary elections]] and suppressed the group through actions allowed under emergency law.<ref name="autogenerated2004">{{Cite book|last= Caraley|first= Demetrios|title= American Hegemony: Preventive War, Iraq, and Imposing Democracy|publisher=[[Academy of Political Science]]|year= 2004|month= April|isbn= 1-8848-5304-8}}</ref> This has led to the imprisonment of activists without trials,<ref name="Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation">{{cite web|author=Choney, Suzanne|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41285248/ns/technology_and_science-tech_and_gadgets/|title=Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[MSNBC]]}}</ref> illegal undocumented hidden detention facilities,<ref name="Mayer">{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/10/30/061030ta_talk_mayer|title=The C.I.A.'s Travel Agent|date= 30 October 2006|accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[The New Yorker]] |author=Mayer, Jane}}</ref><ref name="Kalla fakta">{{cite web|url=http://www.trojkan.se/temp/Reportage/KF_Extraordinary_Rendition/English_version/The%20Broken%20Promise%20-%20%20How%20we%20did%20it.doc|title=Striptease brevpapperl Agent|date= 18 May 2004|accessdate=28 January 2011|publisher=trojkan.se|author=Fakta, Kalla}}</ref> and rejecting university, mosque, and newspaper staff members based on their political inclination.<ref name="independents fight for hearts and minds">{{cite web|author=Shenker, Jack|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/nov/22/egypt-elections-muslim-brotherhood-ndp|title=Egyptian Elections: Independents Fight for Hearts and Minds in 'Fixed Ballot'|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=22 November 2010|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> A [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|parliamentary election]] in December 2010 was preceded by a media crackdown, arrests, candidate bans (particularly of the Muslim Brotherhood), and allegations of fraud involving the near unanimous victory by the ruling party in parliament.<ref name="emerlaw" /> Human rights organizations estimate that in 2010 between 5,000 and 10,000 people were in long-term detention without charge or trial.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Press release]]|publisher=[[Amnesty International]]|title=Egypt: Keep Promise to Free Detainees by End of June: Joint Statement|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/MDE12/027/2010/en|date=29 June 2010|accessdate=4 February 2011|date=29 June 2010}}</ref><ref name="Death Triggers Cairo Protests">{{cite web|author=Holder, R. Clemente|url=http://www.washington-report.org/backissues/0794/9407060.htm|title=Egyptian Lawyer's Death Triggers Cairo Protests|work=[[Washington Report on Middle East Affairs]]|date=July/August 1994|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
